Selected Answer: C
A technician needs to change an incoming fiber line into an RJ45 copper connection for uplinking a new switch. Which of the following would BEST satisfy this requirement? 

another bad question. It lean towards C. If the switch has an SFP port then you would use that along with a transceiver.

Selected Answer: A
A. Media converter

A media converter is a device that can convert signals between different media types, such as from fiber optics to copper (RJ45). In this case, if a technician needs to change an incoming fiber line into an RJ45 copper connection for uplinking a new switch, a media converter would be the most appropriate solution.

Selected Answer: B
To understand the paths that network traffic takes, the new engineer should review the Logical network diagram. The logical diagram provides an overview of how devices are interconnected and how data flows within the network, showing the logical relationships between devices, subnets, and network segments.

questions.question_text: A new engineer at a company is working to understand the network. Which of the following diagrams should the engineer review to understand the paths traffic takes?

A network technician is attempting to increase throughput by configuring link port aggregation between a Gigabit Ethernet distribution switch and a Fast Ethernet access switch. Which of the following is the BEST choice concerning speed and duplex for all interfaces that are participating in the link aggregation?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The access switches are fast ethernet so only 100mb/full duplex. All interfaces would need to be set to the highest possible link speed of all devices, which is 100mb. The gigabit interfaces would need to be set to 100/full.

I am gonna chime in and agree D is the correct answer. Other nerds think it is fine to configure 1 end 1GB, but the question is CLEAR that you are configuring BOTH with a setting. I dont think you can configure the fast ethernet side to 1gb, but this question is BS regardless.
gigabit ethernet means it can operate up to 1gb doesnt mean it only operates at 1gb. fast ethernet has a max of 100mb. That being said 100mb would be the maximum speed allowed in their communication

Selected Answer: B
The configuration of Full duplex and 1GB speed is the best choice for the link aggregation because it represents the optimal settings for the interfaces. However, the actual speed of data transfer will be limited by the capabilities of the devices involved. The reason we still choose 1GB speed in the configuration is to ensure that we are not artificially limiting the potential throughput. If the Fast Ethernet switch is ever upgraded to a switch that supports higher speeds, we won’t need to reconfigure the link aggregation. while the Fast Ethernet switch can’t fully utilize the 1GB speed setting, the full duplex setting and the readiness for higher speed devices make this configuration the best choice for maximizing throughput.
Faster Ethernet = 100, GBit Ethernet = 1000 .. weakest link = 100. Answer = 100. Me = Smart.

Selected Answer: D
Bing AI Says D

The best choice for speed and duplex for all interfaces participating in the link aggregation would be Option D: Full duplex and 100MB speed.

Here’s why:

The Fast Ethernet access switch has a maximum speed of 100MB, so the link aggregation cannot exceed this speed.
Full duplex allows for simultaneous bidirectional data transmission, which can effectively double the throughput.
Therefore, to maximize throughput, the interfaces should be configured for full duplex operation at the maximum supported speed of 100MB. This ensures that the link aggregation operates at the highest possible speed while allowing for bidirectional data transmission.

comments.content: No it won't. You have 100mb and 1000mb / 1Gig connection within the chain. Weakest link is 100mb no matter how fast previous or following connections can theoretically transfer. It's called a "bottleneck".

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Option B will maximise potential throughput

Selected Answer: B
Option B

Selected Answer: B
In the scenario where a network technician is configuring link port aggregation between a Gigabit Ethernet distribution switch and a Fast Ethernet access switch, the BEST choice concerning speed and duplex for all interfaces participating in the link aggregation would be:

B. Full duplex and 1GB speed

I apologize for any confusion. Option D (Full duplex and 100MB speed) would work for link aggregation as well, but it might not provide as much bandwidth as the 1GB speed option (Option B).

The choice between 100MB and 1GB depends on the capabilities of the devices and the desired level of throughput. If the devices support Gigabit Ethernet (1GB) and you want to maximize throughput, Option B (Full duplex and 1GB speed) would be the better choice.

If, for some reason, the devices involved only support Fast Ethernet (100MB), then Option D would be a valid choice, but keep in mind that the overall throughput would be limited to 100MB. In modern networks, Gigabit Ethernet is more common, so Option B is often the preferred choice for link aggregation to achieve higher throughput.

Its gigabit so take full advantage of 1GB duplex 
Gpt: D
Full duplex and 100MB speed? going from 1gig to 100mbps so duplex mismatch

comments.content: that's a speed mismatch, not a duplex mismatch. A duplex mismatch is if one device is configured for half and the other full duplex.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The junior network engineer is attempting to prevent VLAN hopping by changing the native network ID to a non-default value that can be consistently applied throughout the network environment.

Explanation:

VLAN hopping is a security vulnerability that can occur in situations where a switch incorrectly forwards traffic between different VLANs that should be isolated from each other. One common method attackers use to exploit VLAN hopping is by sending frames with 802.1Q tags (VLAN tags) that belong to different VLANs, causing the switch to incorrectly forward the traffic between VLANs.

questions.question_text: A junior network engineer is trying to change the native network ID to a non-default value that can then be applied consistently throughout the network environment. Which of the following issues is the engineer attempting to prevent?
Which of the following BEST prevents unauthorized access to spare workstation inventory?

discussion.content: Its without a doubt D. Locking Cabinets. Think of Amazon Smart Lockers, those are used for contactless package pickup.

Selected Answer: E
I'm inclined to say D (Locking Cabinet), but after reading CompTIA's N+ Review Guide, I'm leaning towards E (Smart Lockers). Read below and tell me what you think. Page 412 and 413 N+ Review Guide 5th edition.

- Locking Cabinets (Can even thwart an attacker from gaining unauthorized access to information or materials. Cabinets are not just used for files; other media and valuables can be on hand, and they should be locked up in cabinets as well. 
- Smart Lockers (In many large tech-driven organizations, these smart lockers can dispense and track electronics for their employees. An Employee has to scan their employee badge, and equipment is automatically checked out to them, and returning the devices requires a similar process.
C locking cabinet

"Locking Cabinets: Lockable cabinets or safes can provide secure storage for individual items, such as media with cryptographic keys or shared password lists. Smart Lockers A smart locker is a cabinet that supports unlocking via a smart card/badge or biometric. Lockers may also have built-in monitoring and surveillance that can alert an administrator when an item is added ore removed." -Official CompTIA Network+ Study Guide

Selected Answer: D
smart locker would for equipment in use by employees, locked cabinet makes more sense where it's spare hardware

Selected Answer: D
locking Cabinet

Selected Answer: D
its D. j904 comment nailed it.
first 3 are mostly good for detecting and the last answer is could work but putting it in some form of locked storaged area is the best between the 2

Selected Answer: D
Pretty sure it would be "D", locking cabinet. In my experience, smart lockers are often used by people visiting data centers to store their phone or keys, and not something you'd store equipment in long term.

comments.content: Hmmmm. rethinking. D is probably more common. But is "more common" "BEST"??? Geez I don't know what to choose. I test on Monday. We'll see how it goes.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: E
Smart lockers usually have features that make them more secure than traditional storage options, like locking mechanisms that prevent anyone but you (with a valid key card or access fob) from entering.

Selected Answer: D
D. Locking cabinet

A locking cabinet physically secures spare workstation inventory, preventing unauthorized access to the equipment. It offers a tangible barrier that restricts entry unless authorized personnel have the necessary keys or access codes.

While the other options can contribute to security measures, they might not provide the same level of physical protection against unauthorized access:
